item.title: How Australia’s Housing Market Became So Out of Reach
item.description: Ballooning property prices and rents are causing serious housing affordability problems in Australia. So how bad is it? And how did it get to this point?
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey, Haidi Lun

item.title: Angola’s Fight Against Corruption Is Losing Momentum, IMF Says
item.description: Angolan President Joao Lourenco’s anti-corruption drive is losing steam, threatening the country’s economic growth outlook, according to the International Monetary Fund.
item.dc:creator: Henrique Almeida, Candido Mendes

media:content.media:description: Joao Lourenco looks on during the 38th African Union (AU) Summit, at the AU Headquarters in Addis Ababa on February 15, 2025. (Photo by Amanuel Sileshi / AFP) (Photo by AMANUEL SILESHI/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Wall Street Sees Higher China Growth, Less Stimulus on US Truce
item.description: Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and other major banks boosted their forecasts for China’s 2025 economic growth, citing a better outlook for exports following the tariff truce with the US.
item.dc:creator: Katia Dmitrieva, Yujing Liu

media:content.media:description: A worker loads bundles of goods onto a truck at an industrial park in Yiwu, Zhejiang Province, China. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: South Korean Think Tank Halves 2025 Growth Forecast to 0.8%
item.description: A South Korean state-funded think tank slashed its outlook for the country’s growth this year, reflecting the fallout from Donald Trump’s tariff campaign on the trade-reliant nation as its presidential race hits full swing.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung in Goyang, South Korea, on April 27.

item.title: Japan’s Key Trade Chiefs Skip Chance to Meet Greer at APEC
item.description: Japan’s Trade Minister Yoji Muto will skip a gathering of trade chiefs this week, a decision that will likely lower Tokyo’s chances of holding meaningful bilateral talks with US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer on the sidelines of the meeting.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Yoji Muto Photographer: Jung Yeon-Je/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Peru Prime Minister Resigns After Backlash From Cabinet Reshuffle
item.description: Peru’s prime minister resigned on Tuesday evening after a last-ditch attempt at a cabinet reshuffle did not placate opposition lawmakers who demanded his ouster.
item.dc:creator: Marcelo Rochabrun

media:content.media:description: Gustavo Adrianzen in 2024.

item.title: Australian Wage Growth Quickens to 3.4% on Tight Jobs Market
item.description: Australia’s wage growth was stronger than expected in the first three months of the year, highlighting the nation’s tight labor market that has been underpinned by a wave of public-sector hiring.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: China Surrounded Xi’s Aide With Seasoned Experts to Seal US Deal
item.description: China’s surprisingly quick agreement with the US to wind back punitive tariff rates put a spotlight on a Chinese negotiating team that features decades worth of technical trade experience alongside a top aide of President Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger, Fran Wang

media:content.media:description: Liao Min, left, He Lifeng, center, and Li Chenggang at a news conference in Geneva on May 11.

item.title: In Trump’s World, Aircraft Are Key to Unlocking Political Favors
item.description: President Donald Trump’s long-held fascination with the world of aviation is proving a useful tool for governments and companies seeking to win his favor.
item.dc:creator: Leen Al-Rashdan

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump boards Air Force One at Joint Base Andrews, Maryland, on May 12.

item.title: New Zealand Saw Record Number of People Depart in March Year
item.description: A record number of people left New Zealand in the year through March, reducing the net gain through immigration to the lowest in more than two years.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Withers

item.title: Milei Scraps Tariffs That Put $2,000 Price Tags on iPhones
item.description: President Javier Milei cut tariffs that made Argentina one of the most expensive places in the world to buy iPhones after decades of protectionist policies, delivering on a campaign promise to open up the economy to trade.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Gillespie, Manuela Tobias

media:content.media:description: Apple’s iPhone 16 costs more than $2,000 in Argentina.

item.title: Trump’s Global Tariffs Face Key Test in US Trade Court
item.description: A group of small businesses urged the US trade court to block President Donald Trump’s “Liberation Day” global tariffs during a court hearing that could have a major impact on the Republican’s economic agenda.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson, Sabrina Willmer, Bob Van Voris

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump holds a chart as he delivers remarks on tariffs during an event in the Rose Garden at the White House in Washington, DC, on April 2. Photographer: Brendan Smialowski/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Trump Says Fed Must Lower Rates After Soft Inflation Report
item.description: President Donald Trump cited a softer-than-expected inflation report to again pressure Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell to lower interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Augusta Saraiva

item.title: Trump and MBS Tout $1 Trillion Pledge as Details Remain Elusive
item.description: President Donald Trump and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman touted a pledge for $1 trillion in commercial deals in Riyadh on Tuesday, a staggering figure that doesn’t quite stand up to scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy, Hadriana Lowenkron, Kate Sullivan, Fiona MacDonald

media:content.media:description: Donald J. Trump and Prince Mohammed bin Salman during a signing ceremony at the Saudi Royal Court in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, on May 13.

item.title: Cheaper Eggs, Pricier Car Rentals: A Look at US April Inflation
item.description: US inflation rose by less than expected in April, helped by steep declines in prices for sporting events, eggs and other groceries.
item.dc:creator: Mark Niquette

item.title: ECB’s Villeroy Says Another Rate Cut Is Likely by Summer
item.description: The European Central Bank will probably lower borrowing costs again by the summer as trade tensions aren’t fueling inflation in the region, Governing Council member Francois Villeroy de Galhau said.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Francois Villeroy de Galhau, governor of the Bank of France, at the VivaTech conference in Paris, France, on Thursday, May 23, 2024. The annual startup and technology events runs until May 25.

item.title: Romania Raises €1.6 Billion in Local Debt Before Tight Vote
item.description: Romania sold more euro-denominated debt on the domestic market than planned, rushing to fill up state coffers ahead of a contentious presidential run-off that’s weighed on the the country’s assets.
item.dc:creator: Peter Laca, Irina Vilcu

media:content.media:description: Campaign posters for presidential candidates in Bucharest.

item.title: Colombian Business Lobby Warns of Risks From a Deal With China
item.description: Colombia’s business lobby warned of risks to local industry from President Gustavo Petro’s plan to join the Chinese Belt and Road Initiative.
item.dc:creator: Oscar Medina

media:content.media:description: Gustavo Petro speaks during the Forum of China and Community of Latin American and Caribbean States (CELAC) in Beijing on May 13.

item.title: Student Loans Drive US Delinquency Rate to Highest Since 2020
item.description: The share of outstanding US consumer debt that’s in delinquency rose in the first quarter to the highest in five years, reflecting an end to the pandemic-era pause on reporting delinquent student loan payments on credit reports.
item.dc:creator: Maria Eloisa Capurro, Jonnelle Marte

media:content.media:description: Graduates listen to a commencement speaker during a university graduation ceremony.

item.title: ECB’s Knot Sees Trade Curbing Inflation and Growth in Near Term
item.description: Uncertainty stemming from US trade policy is likely to curb inflation and economic growth in the near term, though its effects on prices are less clear beyond that, according to European Central Bank Governing Council member Klaas Knot.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Jacob, Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: Klaas Knot

item.title: UK Taxpayers to Make Money on BOE Lending to Banks, Reeves Says
item.description: The Bank of England is expected to make a profit on the cash it provides high street lenders, a small consolation for UK taxpayers as losses on its flagship quantitative-easing program continue to mount.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick

item.title: Bulgarian President’s Proposal for Euro Referendum Blocked
item.description: Bulgaria’s parliament speaker dismissed an initiative by President Rumen Radev to hold a referendum on euro adoption as the nation moves closer to joining the single currency next year.
item.dc:creator: Slav Okov

media:content.media:description: Rumen Radev

item.title: Poland’s Domanski Sees EU Defense Fund Agreement This Month
item.description: Polish Finance Minister Andrzej Domanski said he expects the European Union to reach a deal this month on a €150 billion ($167 billion) fund to boost the bloc’s defense capabilities.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Migliaccio, Jorge Valero, Kamil Kowalcze

media:content.media:description: Andrzej Domanski, Poland's finance minster, during a news conference following the Economic and Financial Affairs Council (ECOFIN) meeting at the European Council headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, on Tuesday, May 13, 2025. A top European Union policymaker said the region should take advantage of investor doubts in the dollar and US Treasuries.

item.title: Softer-Than-Expected Inflation Points to Muted Tariff Fallout
item.description: US inflation rose by less than forecast in April amid tame prices for clothing and new cars, suggesting little urgency so far by companies to pass along the cost of higher tariffs to consumers.
item.dc:creator: Augusta Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Shoppers at an Ikea store in New York. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: Here Are the Key Takeaways From the US CPI Report for April
item.description: Here are five key takeaways from today’s April US consumer price index report:
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

media:content.media:description: Shoppers at an Ikea store in New York. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: US Small-Business Optimism Declines for a Fourth Straight Month
item.description: Sentiment among US small businesses deteriorated for a fourth straight month in April as firms grew more downbeat about the economic outlook and sales prospects amid higher tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Nazmul Ahasan

media:content.media:description: Businesses in the Flushing, in the Queens borough of New York.

item.title: Brazil Central Bank Vows Tight Monetary Policy for Prolonged Period
item.description: Brazil’s central bank sees the need for tighter monetary policy for a longer period due to unanchored inflation forecasts, according to the minutes to the last interest rate decision published on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Martha Viotti Beck

media:content.media:description: The Central Bank of Brazil headquarters in Brasilia. Photographer: Andressa Anholete/Bloomberg

item.title: Bessent Says EU Is Plagued by ‘Collective Action Problem’
item.description: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the European Union suffers from a “collective action problem” that’s hampering trade negotiations, downplaying the possibility of a quick agreement with the US’s largest trading relationship.
item.dc:creator: Jordan Fabian

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent

item.title: India Proposes First Counter Move Against Trump’s Tariff Regime
item.description: India has proposed levies on some US goods in response to Washington’s duties on steel and aluminum, marking its first retaliation against President Donald Trump’s tariff regime, even as the two countries move closer to finalizing a trade deal.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Srivastava

media:content.media:description: A crane is used to load stainless steel coils onto a train container at Jindal Stainless Ltd. plant in Jajpur, Odisha, India, on Thursday, April 24, 2025. India is scheduled to release industrial production figures on April 28. Photographer: Anindito Mukherjee/Bloomberg

item.title: US-China Truce Likely to Avert Recession But Not Slowdown
item.description: The Trump administration’s temporary trade deal with China didn’t arrive in time to prevent a slowdown in the US economy, forecasters say, even if it reduces the risk of a full-blown recession later this year.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard, Jonnelle Marte

media:content.media:description: The YM Welcome container ship docked at the Port of Long Beach in Long Beach, California, US, on Monday, April 28, 2025. Since the US raised levies on China to 145% in early April, cargo shipments have plummeted, perhaps by as much as 60%, according to one estimate.
